coredata.dc:description: This study presents a spray pyrolysis technique for fabricating mesoporous cerium oxide nanoparticles (MCNs) with tunable properties. The MCNs were extensively characterized by their morphology, crystallinity, optical properties, and surface area through transmission electron microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, UV−vis spectroscopy, and BET adsorption isotherms. We manipulated synthesis parameters to tailor these characteristics, and subsequently evaluated the ability of MCNs to load and release the cationic probe Rhodamine 6G, demonstrating their responsiveness to pH variations. The particles showed high entrapment efficiency (up to 40 %), pH-responsive release, and pore-size-dependent release performance. Additionally, the biocompatibility of MCNs was confirmed by assessing their impact on the viability of HEK293 cells. The findings indicate that the fabricated MCNs hold promise for targeted nano-therapeutic applications, particularly within acidic microenvironments such as tumor sites.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: This study presents a spray pyrolysis technique for fabricating mesoporous cerium oxide nanoparticles (MCNs) with tunable properties. The MCNs were extensively characterized by their morphology, crystallinity, optical properties, and surface area through transmission electron microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, Raman spectroscopy, UV−vis spectroscopy, and BET adsorption isotherms. We manipulated synthesis parameters to tailor these characteristics, and subsequently evaluated the ability of MCNs to load and release the cationic probe Rhodamine 6G, demonstrating their responsiveness to pH variations. The particles showed high entrapment efficiency (up to 40 %), pH-responsive release, and pore-size-dependent release performance. Additionally, the biocompatibility of MCNs was confirmed by assessing their impact on the viability of HEK293 cells. The findings indicate that the fabricated MCNs hold promise for targeted nano-therapeutic applications, particularly within acidic microenvironments such as tumor sites.

ce:list-item.ce:para: Data will be made available on request.

ce:section.ce:para: Recently, CeO2 nanoparticles, known as nanoceria, have attracted increasing attention due to their unique intrinsic features, including the facile interconversion between Ce4+ and Ce3+, abundant oxygen vacancies, high stability, and excellent biocompatibility [1]. The redox activity of nanoceria is strongly influenced by the ratio of Ce3+/Ce4+ and the concentration of oxygen vacancies, which increases with decreasing the crystallite size of nanoceria [2]. However, individual nanoceria is less stable, tending to sinter or dissolve under practical conditions, thereby reducing their surface area. To overcome these limitations, mesostructured CeO2 particles composed of small nanoceria clusters have been assembled to maintain stability and reusability without losing their intrinsic features [1]. Importantly, mesoporous CeO2 nanoparticles (MCNs) offer a higher surface area, enhancing their loading capacity and providing more adsorption or reaction sites [3]. Recent literatures clearly evidence the interest of developing the mesoporous carrier-based nanoplatforms for biological purpose [4-6]. Moreover, their physicochemical properties can be adjusted by tailoring their structure. In this regard, various methods for synthesizing MCNs have been developed and were recently reviewed extensively by Wang et al. [1]. MCNs are generally prepared via conventional solution-based routes such as precipitation and sol-gel process. These methods are conducted by the acid/base-catalyzed hydrolysis and condensation of the cerium precursor in the presence of soft or hard templates. However, these methods face several drawbacks that limit their practical applications. For instance, in the precipitation method, after the addition of ammonia as a precipitating agent, the formed particles (Ce(OH)4) are separated from the reaction solution due to their very low aqueous solubility. Therefore, the concentration of cerium precursors in the solution decreases constantly during the precipitation, leading to the difficult control of the nanocrystal growth process [7]. Furthermore, during heat treatment, soft templates may decompose prematurely, leading to the collapse of the mesoporous structure before CeO2 crystallization is complete [8]. On the other hand, solution-based techniques, especially in the case of hard templates, are usually multi-step and time-consuming processes and may require hazardous etchants for template removal, which causes problems in using them for large-scale and continuous operation [9].

As an alternative method, we present a continuous aerosol-based method for synthesizing spherical MCNs using spray pyrolysis of cerium salt without the need for templates, and in some cases, with the addition of Pluronic P123 block copolymer as a soft template. In this method, the precursor is introduced as aerosol droplets into a heated tube furnace reactor. Therefore, each droplet may be regarded as an individual microreactor while passing through the furnace, which prevents the phase separation between the CeO2 and templates [10]. Importantly, because of the short reaction time, which causes fast nucleation and crystal growth inside the droplets, not only small crystallites are formed, but also the structural collapse can be suppressed [11]. Furthermore, this approach can potentially be upgraded for continuous and large-scale synthesis of MCNs.

Nanoceria is extensively used in various fields of environmental catalysis [12]. However, it has recently attracted increasing attention in the field of nanomedicines, including Alzheimer's disease [13], tissue engineering [14], and wound healing [15]. Moreover, in healthy cells, it acts as an antioxidant by scavenging reactive oxygen species (ROS). Therefore, it could protect them, while in the acidic tumor microenvironment, it acts as a pro-oxidant by generating ROS and kills cancer cells [16]. Furthermore, small crystallite sizes and abundant oxygen vacancies in cerium oxide nanoparticles have been shown to enhance catalytic activities and ROS scavenging capabilities, making them promising candidates for antioxidant treatments [17,18].Interestingly, it was recently suggested that nanoceria because of its unique pharmacological properties could serve as a promising preclinical candidate in the fight against the SARS-CoV-2 coronavirus [19]. We thus explored the application of the designed CeO2 particles as the drug delivery vectors, i.e. to take advantage of the porosity of particles for the loading. Then, a cationic probe, namely the Rhodamine 6 G, was loaded inside the resulting CeO2 particles. The aim is to examine the possible correlation between the properties of the elaborated particles (porosity, state of charge in aqueous solution…) as a function of their loading capacity and to see if a stimuli-controlled release is conceivable according to the isoelectric point of the particles in aqueous media. Finally, the toxicity of the designed cerium oxide particles was also investigated.

Overall, this study introduces a novel aerosol-assisted spray pyrolysis technique for synthesizing MCNs, highlighting significant advancements in material synthesis and characterization. By employing a soft template, the method produces nanoparticles with enhanced surface areas and controlled mesoporosity, which are critical for various applications. Moreover, the unique conditions of the spray pyrolysis process result in smaller crystallite sizes and higher densities of oxygen vacancies. Additionally, the study elucidates the optical properties of the MCNs, demonstrating a correlation between crystallite size, band gap, and light absorption capabilities. These findings offer novel insights and a deeper understanding of material behavior, propelling the field of surface and interface science forward by highlighting the potential for improved performance in various applications, such as drug delivery.

Cerium(III) nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O, purity ≥ 99 %), Pluronic P123 (tri-block co-polymer: EO20PO70EO20), CeO2 powder (< 25 nm particle size), absolute ethanol (EtOH), and Rhodamine 6 G were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of spherical MCNs by the spray pyrolysis process
ce:section.ce:para: In this work, spherical MCNs were synthesized via spray pyrolysis, using cerium nitrate as the metal source. The synthesis was conducted both in the absence of any template [20] and in the presence of Pluronic P123 (a tri-block copolymer: EO20PO70EO20) as a soft template [10]. In the first experiment, 6.2 g of Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O (hereafter referred to as CeN) was dissolved in 100 mL of deionized water. The solution was then atomized using a nebulizer (Palas GmbH AGK-2000) operated by air with a flow rate of 9 L/min into a tube furnace with an inner diameter of 26 mm and a length of 65 cm, corresponding to a mean residence time of approximately 43 ms for the aerosol in the tube furnace reactor at 400 °C. The powders collected on filter paper were calcined in air at 400 °C for 4 h using a heating ramp of 1 °C min−1. The particles obtained before and after calcination are henceforth referred to as H-CeO2 and H-CeO2-C, respectively, where "H" stands for Hollow, and "C" denotes Calcined. In the second experiment, CeN and Pluronic P123 were dissolved in absolute ethanol. The mixture solution was sprayed with the nebulizer (Palas GmbH AGK-2000) operated by N2 with a flow rate of 1 L/min into a tube furnace with an inner diameter of 26 mm and a length of 98 cm, corresponding to a mean residence time of approximately 1.3 s for the aerosol in the tube furnace reactor at 480 °C. Finally, the template was removed using the same calcination process. The particles before and after calcination will be denoted as M-CeO2 and M-CeO2 -C (M = Mesoporous), respectively. For comparative analysis, commercially available CeO2 particles with a diameter of less than 25 nm were utilized, referred to as Comm-CeO2, where "Comm" indicates Commercial.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Determination of the isoelectric point (pI) of CeO2 particles in aqueous suspension
ce:section.ce:para: The isoelectric point (pI) of the suspension of CeO2 particles was determined by adjusting the pH of the suspensions to values ranging from 2 to 12. For this purpose, suspensions of cerium oxide particles were prepared at various pH levels. The pH adjustment was achieved by the careful addition of 0.1 M NaOH to increase the pH or 0.1 M HCl to decrease the pH, as necessary. Following pH adjustment, each sample was thoroughly mixed to ensure uniformity. To determine the pI, each sample, analyzed in triplicate to ensure reproducibility, was subjected to Zeta potential measurements using a Zetasizer. The isoelectric point was identified as the pH at which the Zeta potential of the cerium oxide particle suspension approached zero, indicating a net neutral surface charge.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Ionic probe loading in cerium oxide particles: investigation using Rhodamine 6G
ce:section.ce:para:
To explore the interaction between cerium oxide particles and Rhodamine 6G, a cationic probe, mixtures were prepared under specific conditions that ensured the cerium oxide particles were negatively charged. These conditions, as determined in this study, favor the adsorption of the positively charged Rhodamine 6 G onto the surface of the particles due to electrostatic attraction. To investigate the probe release behavior, the probe-loaded CeO2 particles will be introduced in a dialysis bag and immersed in different pH (3 or 7), keeping the final dialysate volume equal to 100 mL. At predetermined intervals, 1 mL of solution outside the dialysis bag will be taken out and replaced with 1 mL of fresh buffer solution. The loading with the fluorescent probe was examined with an optical fluorescence ZEISS microscope.

Size and Zeta potential measurements were performed using a Zetasizer Nano-ZS (Malvern Instrument, USA). The Zeta potential and isoelectric points (pI) of the cerium oxide particle suspensions were determined using a Zetasizer Nano-ZS (Malvern Instrument, USA). Size with the particles suspended in 0.01 g/L in methanol. The intensity–intensity time correction function was analyzed by the cumulative method. Each measurement was repeated eight times. The mean value of the hydrodynamic diameter was calculated from the diffusion measurement using the Stokes–Einstein equation. In all cases, standard deviation was always lower than 5 %.

Structural characterization was performed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using a D8 advance diffractometer (Bruker, Champs sur Marne, France) (Cu Kα radiation). Data were recorded over a 2Ɵ range from 20 to 90° by step of 0.02° at an incident wavelength λ of 1.54056 Å. The average crystallite sizes of powders were determined using Scherrer's equation (Eq. (2)). In the equation, k = 0.90 is the shape factor, λ is the X-ray wavelength of Cu Ka radiation, β is the specified peak's full−width half-maximum (FWHM) of the respective diffraction peak (in units of radians), and θ is the Bragg angle.

k λ

θ

UV–visible absorption spectroscopy was conducted using a SPECORD 200 (Analytik Jena), covering a wavelength range from 200 to 700 nm at room temperature. The optical gap was calculated using the Tauc plot method [21]. The Raman spectrum was obtained using a SENTERRA spectrometer (Bruker) employing a semiconductor laser (λ = 532 nm) at room temperature.

The structure and morphology of CeO2 particles were examined using an optical fluorescence ZEISS microscope (LSM 700 Laser Scanning Microscope, Carl Zeiss, France), a Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM JEOL JEM2100, 160 kV) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Zeiss DSM Gemini 982, 5 kV).

Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were recorded with an ASAP 2020 from Micromeritics GmbH. The specific surface area was calculated using the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Pore size distributions were derived from the adsorption branches of the isotherms utilizing the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) model.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Toxicity assay of cerium oxide particles
ce:section.ce:para: HEK293 cells were grown in Dulbecco's Minimal Essential Medium (DMEM, Invitrogen) supplemented with 1 % Penicillin/Streptomycin, and 10 % Fetal Bovine Serum (FBS) and maintained in a humidified incubator at 37 °C, 5 % CO2. Cells were seeded in a 96-well plate (80 % confluence) for cell viability assays. After seeding, cells were incubated for 24 h in DMEM medium supplemented with 10 % FBS containing different concentrations of cerium oxide particles. Particles were sonicated prior to use. Photocolorimetric determination of cytotoxicity was assessed using Cell Counting Kit 8 (WST-8) according manufacturer instructions (Abcam, Ab228554). It was prepared by adding CCK8 in DMEM complemented FBS in a 1:10 dilution and 100 μl of the dye was loaded into each well and cells were incubated in a 37 °C, 5 % CO2 incubator for 1 h. The absorbance was measured by using a ClarioStar plate reader (BMG Labtech, Ger) at the optical density of 460 nm. Measures were performed in duplicate and five independent experiments performed. Results were calculated as a percentage of the untreated control. SDS 1 % was used as a positive control. IC50 was calculated using Prism GraphPad software and represented as 95 % confidence interval. Cells treated with 100 µg/ml of each nanoparticles for 24 h were visualized using an EVOS M5000 (Invitrogen) at 40x.

Herein, the central aim of the present work is to design tailor-made mesoporous CeO2 nanoparticles (MCNs) which can be used as cargo delivery systems. This work is concerned with (i) an adjustable aerosol-based approach to produce MCNs with controlled properties, (ii) the MCNs will be used to favor the probe loading and (iii) conducting toxicity assays on the designed particles. We hypothesize that the unique physicochemical features of MCNs are linked to the experimental conditions used to produce these materials. Therefore, we investigate the effect of the processing parameters on the morphology, porosity, particle size, and crystallinity of MCNs synthesized by a spray pyrolysis method. Subsequently, we investigate the physicochemical conditions and cargo loading/release of the designed particle, i.e. MCNs with various particle sizes may exhibit different probe/drug loading capacities and release rates. Finally, we assess the cytotoxicity of the tailor-made particles, aiming to underscore their safety profile for potential biomedical applications.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of MCNs by the spray pyrolysis process
ce:section.ce:para: Mesoporous CeO2 nanoparticles (MCNs) were synthesized via spray pyrolysis, utilizing cerium nitrate both without any templates and with Pluronic P123 as a soft template [10].

TEM images of the obtained samples are shown in Fig. 1 . H-CeO2 and H-CeO2 -C samples exhibited spherical morphology with hollow structure (Fig. 1a, b). This can be explained by the fact that after the atomization of the precursor solution, the droplets undergo solvent evaporation and thermal decomposition of CeN in the furnace. Since the melting temperature of CeN (60 °C) is low, CeN melts before water is completely evaporated and the molten salts may prevent the removal of the entrapped water, causing the creation of hollow cavities [20]. SEM image of a broken H-CeO2 particle is also shown in the inset of Fig. 1a to confirm the hollow interior of H-CeO2. The prepared M-CeO2 -C particles are spherical, which is composed of tiny nanoparticles assembled together (Fig. 1c). The formation of M-CeO2 -C particles in the presence of Pluronic P123 involves a self-assembly mechanism aided by the block copolymer. Upon atomization during the spray pyrolysis process, the precursor solution containing the cerium nitrate and Pluronic P123 experiences rapid solvent evaporation. At the same time, the cerium ions may penetrate the micellar structures formed by the P123 molecules. As the temperature increases within the furnace, the cerium ions undergo nucleation and growth inhibited by the confines of the template, leading to a well-ordered assembly of cerium oxide nanocrystals. Calcination process at 400 °C calcination process not only removes the template effectively but also promotes the crystallization of CeO2, forming the robust mesoporous structure observed in M-CeO2 -C particles. The resulting particles comprising tiny cerium oxide nanoparticles that have assembled in a mesoporous structure. Moreover, the TEM image of Comm-CeO2 nanoparticles is shown in Fig. 1d, which are severely agglomerated.

The textural characteristics of the synthesized samples were investigated through nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms. As shown in Fig. 2 , all the aerosol-generated samples present a typical type IV isotherm with a H2 shaped hysteresis loop, which is typical for mesoporous materials. However, Comm-CeO2 shows H3 typed hysteresis loop, which indicates that the pores in Comm-CeO2 particles arise from the random aggregation of nanoparticles rather than an ordered mesoporous structure. The calculated BET specific surface area, pore volume, and average pore size of samples are summarized in Table 1 . Notably, the specific surface area of M-CeO2 -C is 167 m2g−1, which is much higher than that of H-CeO2 -C and Comm-CeO2 samples. This discrepancy can be attributed to the differences in synthesis approaches, specifically the use of a soft template in the formation of M-CeO2 -C particles. In the synthesis of H-CeO2 and H-CeO2 -C, where no template was used, the cerium oxide particles have the freedom to grow in a less controlled manner, resulting in larger sizes and consequently a lower specific surface area. Conversely, in case of M-CeO2 -C particles, the template acts as a spatial constraint, limiting the growth of cerium oxide within the confines of the self-assembled polymer structure. This not only prevents the formation of larger particles but also yields a network of mesopores that greatly enhance the specific surface area. The pore size distribution curves, shown in Fig. 2b, further illustrate the differences between the samples. The decrease in BJH pore size of M-CeO2 after calcination can be attributed to the removal of the Pluronic P123 template and the subsequent densification of the cerium oxide framework. During the calcination process, the organic template decomposes, leading to the formation of a more rigid and interconnected network of cerium oxide. This process may result in the contraction of the pores. Furthermore, the high temperatures used during calcination can promote sintering, which further reduces the pore size.

X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed to determine the crystal structure of the cerium oxide samples, as shown in Fig. 3 a. All samples exhibited distinct diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 28.5°, 33.1°, 47.5°, 56.3°, 59.1°, 69.5°, 76.8°, 79.1°, and 88.4° These peaks correspond to the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), (420), and (422) planes, characteristic of the face-centered cubic (FCC) fluorite structure of CeO2 [22]. Furthermore, the average crystallite sizes of all the samples were calculated using Scherrer's equation, (as presented in Table 1). It was observed that the average crystal size of both H-CeO2 and M-CeO2 increased after calcination. Specifically, the average crystal size of H-CeO2 increased from 3.7 nm to 6.4 nm, and for M-CeO2, it increased from 3.9 nm to 6.2 nm. This increase is attributed to the sintering effect [23]. Importantly, the average crystallite size for M-CeO2 -C is 6.2 nm, which is nearly 2.8 times smaller than that of Comm-CeO2, with a crystallite size of 17.2 nm. This significant difference in crystallite size can be reasoned to the unique conditions within the spray pyrolysis process. As the atomized precursor solution forms droplets that serve as individual microreactors, they undergo a rapid process with a short residence time in the furnace (typically just a few seconds). This rapid process likely leads to a partial suppression of crystal growth. Consequently, the aerosol-generated CeO2 particles are formed with smaller crystallite sizes, which in turn suggests a higher density of surface defects.

Raman spectroscopy has been proven as a powerful method to examine the oxygen vacancies of CeO2 materials [24]. As shown in Fig. 3b, Comm-CeO2 exhibits a sharp peak located at about 465 cm−1. This peak can be assigned to the F2g mode of fluorite-structured CeO2, which corresponds to the symmetric breathing mode of the oxygen atoms around Ce4+ ions [25]. However, this intense peak was red-shifted to 460, 462, and 462 cm−1 for H-CeO2 and H-CeO2 -C, and M-CeO2 -C samples, respectively, and its shape became broadened and asymmetrical. Generally, the position of Raman peaks is closely related to the interatomic force. Therefore, the shift in F2g mode was attributed to the change in the Ce-O bond length, as well as the change the lattice spacing. The relationship between the Raman shift in F2g mode and the variation of the lattice parameter can be explained from the following equation (Eq. (3)) [26]:
(3)
Δ
α = −
Δ
ω
α 0
/
3 γ
ω 0
where Δα is the change in lattice constant, Δω is the frequency shift of the Raman mode, ω0 is the Raman frequency of bulk CeO2 (465 cm−1), α0 is the lattice constant of bulk CeO2 (0.5411 nm), and γ is the Grüneisen constant (1.24). The lattice constant estimated by Eq. (3) for H-CeO2, H-CeO2 -C, M-CeO2 -C, and Comm-CeO2 samples are 5.427 Å, 5.420 Å, 5.420 Å, and 5.411 Å, respectively. Combined results from Raman and XRD indicate that the lattice parameter of CeO2 expands with decreasing crystallite size. Phokha et al. [27] reported that this expansion is possibly owing to the introduction of Ce3+ ions and consequently more oxygen vacancies into the lattice structure. Ce3+ ions have a larger ionic radius (1.034 Å) than that of the Ce4+ ions (0.92 Å). Therefore, with decreasing the crystallite size, the concentration of Ce3+ ions and the number of oxygen vacancies in the particles increase. In addition to F2g mode, a weak peak at 598 cm−1 is identified in the enlarged scale of Raman spectra from 350 to 700 cm−1, which is ascribed to the defected-induced (D) mode related to oxygen vacancies caused by the existence of Ce3+ [28]. It was found that the redox activity of CeO2 is related to the intensity of F2g and D modes [29,30]. Therefore, the intensity ratio of ID/IF2g can be used to estimate the oxygen vacancy concentration. As listed in Table 1, the concentration of oxygen vacancy follows the sequence of H-CeO2 > H-CeO2 -C > M-CeO2 -C > Comm-CeO2. It should be noted that measurements for the M-CeO2 particles prior to calcination were not conducted. The presence of Pluronic P123 in the synthesis process, introduces organic compounds that could interfere with the spectroscopic analysis.

Furthermore, the optical properties of the ceria samples have been examined. Fig. 3c shows normalized UV−vis spectra of the H-CeO2 -C, M-CeO2 -C, and Comm-CeO2 samples. All the samples display strong absorption bands in the UV region. However, the obvious redshifts of the absorption edges are observed for the H-CeO2 -C and M-CeO2 -C samples. From the UV−vis spectra, the optical band gap (E g) values of the O(2p) → Ce(4f) transition were calculated (Fig. 3d). The E g values obtained for H-CeO2 -C, M-CeO2 -C, and Comm-CeO2 samples are 2.3, 2.9, and 3.42 eV, respectively, indicating that the band gap decreases with decreasing crystal size. It has been reported that the shift of optical E g is an electrostatic potential effect due to a cerium valence change. An increase of the Ce3+ ions concentration caused the decrease of E g value [31]. However, for the H-CeO2 -C sample, the hollow structure may facilitate enhanced light absorption and scattering, contributing to a lower Eg value compared to that of M-CeO2 -C. The hollow cavities within the H-CeO2 -C particles can act as light traps, promoting multiple internal reflections that extend the interaction of light within the material [32,33]. Note that UV–Vis spectroscopic analysis of M-CeO2 and H-CeO2 particles prior to calcination was omitted to prevent potential interference from synthesis-related impurities.

The particle sizes are in the range of 300 nm for all of them under the studied condition. Then, the isoelectric points (pI) of the CeO2 samples were determined by measuring the Zeta potential of particle suspensions across a pH range from 2 to 11. The relationship between Zeta potential and pH is presented in Fig. 4 . A linear interpolation of these data points yielded an isoelectric point of 8.3 for the commercial cerium oxide particles (Comm-CeO2). This result is in agreement with the work by Quik et al. [34]. and Van Hoecke et al. [35], who found an isoelectric point of 8.0 and 7.9 respectively, for the same nature particles. The pI values of M-CeO2, H-CeO2 -C, and H-CeO2 particles are around 5.5–6. The observed discrepancy in pI values when compared to Comm-CeO2 particles is likely due to the presence of calcium and trace amounts of other metals, which are possibly impurities originating from the production precursors, as reported by Rodea-Palomares et al. [36]

ce:section.ce:section-title: Cationic probe loading efficiency and pH-Responsive release profile in CeO2 samples
ce:section.ce:para: In this section, the influence of the physicochemical characteristics of various CeO2 samples on their efficacy for loading and subsequent release of cationic probes was investigated. The Comm-CeO2 was employed as a reference to compare the performance between commercial particles and the newly synthesized ones. In this regard, we explored the loading capacity of cerium oxide samples for molecules with varying charges, specifically focusing on the cationic fluorescent probe, Rhodamine 6 G. It should be mentioned that unmodified CeO2 particles exhibit no intrinsic fluorescence. However, CeO2 particles loaded with Rhodamine 6 G displayed distinct fluorescence, indicative of the incorporation of the probe, as presented in Fig. 5 . This fluorescence confirms the successful entrapment of the fluorescent probe within all particle types under examination.

We also examined the possibility of loading Rhodamine 6 G inside the CeO2 samples. Rhodamine 6 G is a small size molecule (a few nanometres); thus, it should easily permeate into the internal volume of particles. Furthermore, Rhodamine 6 G is a positively charged molecule and CeO2 particles are negatively charged (below - 20 mV) under the physicochemical condition of loading, thus electrostatic interactions should occur which promote Rhodamine 6 G entrapment inside the CeO2 particles. To prove this, the Zeta potential value of CeO2 particles loaded with Rhodamine 6 G was evaluated and was around +20 mV. This supports our assumption. The probe-loading of the CeO2 particles was found to be 18 %, 25 %, 34 %, 24 % and 40 % for Comm-CeO2, H-CeO2, H-CeO2 -C, M-CeO2 and M-CeO2 -C, respectively. This can be explained by the fact that probe-loading values are mainly connected to the textural properties of particles such as specific pore size, surface area, and pore volume that are presented in Table 1. From these results, it could be deduced that the presence of a high BET surface area promotes probe loading. This finding is in accordance with the results of Belbekhouche et al. [37] who entrapped Rhodamine b inside the mesoporous silica particles with the large pore. Moreover, the release of Rhodamine 6 G from the CeO2 samples was investigated at two pH levels, i.e. pH 3.0 and pH 7.0. As seen in Fig. 6 , an initial burst release of this chemical was noticed within 5 min no matter the investigated pH. This burst release may be assigned to the filling of the pores with the aqueous medium which favors the initial surge. The tendency reveals that the Rhodamine 6 G release of all investigated CeO2 particles was promoted by decreasing the pH value. Without exception, the fast release was achieved with a final plateau whose maximum value was strongly dependent on the pH of the release media and on the considered particle system. At pH 7.0, the maximum probe release of 40–70 % was obtained, whereas this was increased at pH 3.0 (70–100 %). A possible statement for this result has been provided by Bui and Choi [38], Reiser et al. [39]. and Belbekhouche et al. [40].. They expounded that this pH dependence might be consistent with changes in electrostatic interactions between the cationic chemical (Rhodamine 6 G) and the CeO2 particle surface at different pH values. At pH 3.0, the fabricated CeO2 particles surface (H-CeO2, H-CeO2 -C, M-CeO2 and M-CeO2 -C) has a net positive charge on the surface and at pH 7.0, this variable becomes negative (Fig. 4). It is important to underline that whatever the pH, Rhodamine 6B remains positively charged. Therefore, at pH 3.0, both the designed CeO2 samples (H-CeO2, H-CeO2 -C, M-CeO2 and M-CeO2 -C) and the Rhodamine 6 G are positively charged (as depicted in Fig. 7 ), which instigate a repulsive effect that promotes the Rhodamine 6 G release from the particle. In contrast, at pH 7.0, the designed CeO2 samples are positively charged (Fig. 4) and Rhodamine 6 G too; in this case, there is a repulsive force, which appears to reduce the release process. This pH-dependent release of the cationic probe from the designed CeO2 particles makes them suitable for pH-triggered drug release inside specific localized acidic areas of intracellular endosomes [41] or diseased cells (e.g. tumor cells). It should be noted that for commercial particles (Comm-CeO2), there is no effect of pH on salting-out because, under these conditions, the charge state of the particles does not vary at pH 3 or pH 7. In fact, these particles remain positively charged (Fig. 4), hence the non-impact pH under these conditions when using these particles. In addition to pH responsiveness, the release kinetics of synthesized CeO2 particles also displayed a dependence on pore size and BET surface area. Fig. 5 highlights the correlation between these textural properties and the rate of Rhodamine 6 G release under identical pH conditions. This behavior could be attributed to the pore confinement effects and the diffusion rate of Rhodamine 6 G through the nanochannels of the CeO2 particles. Consistently, particles with larger pores and higher BET surface areas exhibited faster Rhodamine 6 G release rates at both pH levels studied.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Impact of pristine MCNs on cell viability
ce:section.ce:para: The biocompatibility of the aerosol-generated mesoporous CeO2 nanoparticles (MCNs) was assessed by examining their effect on the viability of HEK293 cells. Fig. 8 illustrates the cell viability after a 24-hour incubation period with varying concentrations of each particle type (10, 50, 100, 500, and 1000 µg/ml) diluted in culture media (DMEM complemented with FBS). The cell viability was determined using the colorimetric CCK-8 assay. Results indicated that particles comm-CeO2 and M-CeO2 did not affect cell viability at all tested concentrations, while particles H-CeO2, H-CeO2 -C and M-CeO2 -C reduced cell viability at concentrations greater than 100 µg/ml. The IC50 could be calculated for H-CeO2 and M-CeO2 -C with values of 250 [30; 2114] µg/mL and 430 [57;3225] µg/mL, respectively. It should be noted that the values given above in square brackets correspond to 95 % confidence intervals. After particles exposure, they are no apparent alterations in cell shape/morphology. These observations suggest that the surface characteristics introduced by the aerosol synthesis and calcination processes, such as increased surface defects or changes in surface chemistry, might enhance interactions with cellular components, leading to a reduction in cell viability. Particularly, the presence of increased surface defects and oxygen vacancies, as indicated by the Raman spectroscopy data, might contribute to the generation of reactive oxygen species or disrupt cellular functions when internalized by cells. Furthermore, the correlation between cytotoxicity and specific surface area, as observed in the particle loading efficiency results, implies a possible relationship between the increased active surface of MCNs and cellular response.

In this work, we report on a continuous aerosol-based approach allowing fabricating spherical MCNs by spray pyrolysis of cerium salt as a metal source without applying any templates, as well in the presence of Pluronic P123 block copolymer as a soft template. Unlike traditional solution-based methods, which are often hindered by decreasing precursor concentrations, premature template decomposition during heat treatment, and complex multi-step processes, our technique offers a continuous, simple, rapid, and scalable alternative for large-scale synthesis. Each droplet within the aerosol acts as an individual microreactor, which facilitates rapid nucleation and crystal growth while preventing structural collapse. The comprehensive characterization of these nanoparticles revealed a tailored morphology, crystallinity, and surface area, which proved essential for their function in biomedical applications. The MCNs exhibit enhanced drug loading and controlled release kinetics, ideal for targeted drug delivery applications. Their small crystallite sizes and abundant oxygen vacancies suggest potential for catalytic and reactive oxygen species (ROS) scavenging activities, making them promising candidates for antioxidant treatments. The entrapment efficiency and release kinetics of Rhodamine 6 G from MCNs highlighted their potential for controlled drug delivery, responding to pH changes that mimic those found in various biological microenvironments, such as tumor sites. The pore-size-dependent release performance further indicates the possibility of fine-tuning the MCNs for specific therapeutic needs. Importantly, the study has demonstrated that while maintaining high entrapment efficiency, the MCNs exhibit a biocompatible profile with HEK293 cells, underscoring their potential for safe application in nano-therapeutics. It should be also noted that while this study demonstrates promising applications of MCNs for cargo-controlled delivery, it has several limitations. The atomization process typically produces polydisperse droplets, resulting in a broad particle size distribution. Furthermore, the use of materials such as Pluronic P123, high-purity ethanol, and nitrogen as a carrier gas may not be cost-effective for large-scale production. Using more economical alternatives, such as water for the solvent and air for the carrier gas, could be beneficial. Additionally, while the study demonstrates some control over the morphology and surface area of nanoparticles, surface modification of MCNs with stimuli-responsive polymers is crucial. These functionalizations aim to make the delivery process highly controllable. Addressing these limitations will be the focus of our future work, as we continue to enhance the development of MCNs for broader biomedical applications.
